Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Initiation of a sex-determining chromosome: insights from sexually dimorphic strawberries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The evolution of sex-determining chromosomes from autosomes is a universal feature of dioecious organisms, and remarkably, the same evolutionary steps seem to occur in animals, fungi and plants. Despite studies in a wide range of organisms, the very earliest stages in this chromosomal transition remain nearly unexplored. Through the use of two closely related species of wild strawberry, and a merger of approaches including genetics, genomics, bioinformatics, ecology and systematics, this research will offer transformative insight into the steps fundamental to this transition. In particular, the genomic fingerprint and selective forces responsible for recombination suppression will be examined in detail. This work will also provide taxonomic diversity and much needed data for comparative genomic studies of sex-determining genomic regions across the flowering plants.

This work will contribute to the promotion of undergraduate, graduate student and postdoc training in genomics, bioinformatics, genetic and ecological experimental design, as well as the development of a middle school curriculum that will focus on genetics in strawberry. It will contribute to society by expanding our specific knowledge of genes for sex-determination, and general knowledge of genetic and genomic diversity in important wild relatives of the cultivated strawberry, as well as provide plant and genomic resources to the wider scientific community via national databases and germplasm repositories. This work will also shed first light on the genomic changes that accompany the co-occurrence of genome merger and separate sexes that is a feature of many plant lineages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of sex chromosomes are thought to be a universal feature of separate-sexed organisms but our understanding of the process is heavily influenced by animal systems, the majority of which have ancient sex chromosomes.  To address this gap in understanding, research on three species of wild strawberries (Fragaria, Rosaceae) with varying degrees of separation of the sexes was conducted. Characterizing the chromosomes that carry sex determining genes and evaluating the underlying similarities in genetic determiners provided valuable insight into the earliest stages of sex chromosome evolution from autosomes. This study also offered key parallels to dynamics seen at later stages in animal systems, that is where a sex determining region is translocated from one chromosome to another.  A wider comparison across multiple species in this young genus revealed at least four transitions from hermaphroditism to separate sexes, and multiple genetic avenues to loss of female function. Within group of species that are progenitors of the cultivated strawberry,  a nascent ZW sex determining system was identified. In addition, detailed genomic and genetic work revealed novel recombination heterogeneity between the sexes, as well as geographic patterns of variation in the sex determining region that may reflect the complexity of plants with polyploid and/or hybrid histories. Thus, this work has provided unique insights into the evolutionary history of sex determining regions in flowering plants as well as adding to our understanding of genetics underlying separate-sexed organisms as a whole.  

This research provided educational and training opportunities for hundreds of students and teachers (graduate students, undergraduate students, high school students, and teachers).  Through the project the PIs developed and implemented ‘The Strawberry Caper’, a hands-on ‘who-done-it?’ science curriculum that meets STEM standards, in genetics, ecology and statistics. Middle school teachers were trained in workshops and supported in the implementation of the curriculum, and a paper was published in a leading education journal. In addition, K-12 teachers conducted basic research in the lab and have implemented novel curriculum related the strawberry research into their class rooms.  The research fostered and promoted diversity in STEM through community partnerships, mentoring of high school and post baccalaureate  students and via presentations to the wider community.
